content: The report highlights DOD's alternative fuel initiatives, including testing, evaluation, and certification of alternative fuels for service fleets. The Navy plans to promote domestic biofuel production with a $170 million investment. Army, Navy, and Air Force have collectively spent $48 million on alternative fuels. The report discusses DOD's alternative fuels policy, including a $170 million investment in biofuel production capacity. It also provides data on DOD's alternative fuels purchases, testing platforms, and certification for fleet-wide use. Additionally, it covers the Navy's biofuel production initiative under the Defense Production Act, recent legislative actions, and appropriated funding. The Navy's biofuel production efforts under the Defense Production Act are discussed in relation to DOD's alternative fuels policy. Section 314 of the FY2012 National Defense Authorization Act assigned oversight of DOD's alternative fuels initiatives to the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Operational Energy Plans and Programs. The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Operational Plans and Programs is responsible for overseeing DOD's alternative fuel activities, investments, and development recommendations. A memorandum issued by Sharon Burke in 2012 outlined the goals of DOD's alternative fuels policy to ensure operational military readiness. Secretary of Defense for Operational Energy Plans and Programs Sharon Burke issued a memorandum outlining DOD's alternative fuels policy goals, including ensuring military readiness, improving battlespace effectiveness, and increasing fuel source options. DOD investments in alternative fuels aim to enhance resilience against supply disruptions, mitigate petroleum price volatility, and improve expeditionary effectiveness. Alternative fuels for DOD use must be drop-in, cost-competitive, and available in sufficient quantities, with desirable characteristics such as non-food crop feedstock production and reduced lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions. The DOD's alternative fuels policy goals include ensuring military readiness, improving battlespace effectiveness, and increasing fuel source options. Alternative fuels must be drop-in, cost-competitive, and have desirable characteristics such as non-food crop feedstock production and reduced greenhouse gas emissions. DOD investments in alternative fuels must be certified as part of the annual operational energy budget certification process. Future investments will be subject to a rigorous, merit-based evaluation. Alternative fuels development initiatives will generally follow three phases, starting with certification. The DOD's alternative fuels development initiatives will follow three phases: Certification, Field Demonstration, and Ongoing Purchases. Alternative fuels will compete with petroleum products for operational quantities. The Army aims to increase the use of renewable/alternative energy, with goals including having at least 25% of energy for tactical power generation derived from alternative sources by 2028. The Air Force aims to acquire 50% of its domestic aviation fuel from alternative sources by 2016 and test all aircraft on a 50:50 alternative fuel blend by 2012. The Navy has set more ambitious goals for alternative fuels. The Navy aims to deploy a "Great Green Fleet" strike group using alternative fuel blends by 2016 and meet 50% of its energy consumption from alternative sources by 2020. This includes reducing liquid fuel usage to 38 million barrels of oil equivalent per year and utilizing nuclear power for 11 million barrels of oil equivalent in 2020. The Department of Defense aims to replace approximately 8 million barrels of petroleum used afloat with unblended alternative fuels by 2020 to achieve the goal of 50% alternative energy consumption. Since 2007, DLA Energy has procured about 1.9 million gallons of various types of alternative fuels for the Army, Navy, and Air Force, totaling $48 million in alternative fuels purchases for engine performance testing and certification. The Department of Defense has purchased various types of alternative fuels, including Fischer-Tropsch fuels and biofuels, such as hydrotreated jet and diesel biofuels. They are also working on obtaining Air Force certification for H-60 Black Hawk helicopters to fly on the 50:50 FT-SPK: JP-8 blend. Testing of other alternative fuels, such as Fischer-Tropsch fuels, alcohol-to-jet, pyrolysis oils, and direct sugar to hydrocarbon, will continue in the future. In June 2011, the Departments of the Navy, Energy, and Agriculture signed a Memorandum of Understanding to support the development of a sustainable commercial biofuels industry. The MOU calls for government investment to support advanced drop-in biofuel plants and refineries that produce biofuels meeting military specifications, are price competitive with petroleum, and have no significant impact on the food supply. The Navy and Department of Energy plan to fund this initiative with $340 million in federal funds, with industry cost-sharing, while the Department of Agriculture will provide an additional $171 million. Awards will be given in two phases: Phase 1 for planning and preliminary designs, and Phase 2 for construction and testing.
